Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: Using Lean LaunchPad to Promote Transfer Students' Persistence in Engineering

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This engineering education research project focuses on improving the success of transfer students through an innovative transition program that utilizes a Lean LaunchPad model. The Lean LaunchPad presents a practice-oriented paradigm for teaching students about innovation and entrepreneurship. It focuses on the startup experience and the skills necessary to develop successful business ventures. By promoting the development of research, analytical thinking, and problem solving skills in engineering students, the Lean LaunchPad approach provides a relevant platform for academic support and experiential learning. Students learn that failure is a necessary part of learning that allows them to gain valuable research, innovation, and design experiences regardless of whether the business case for an idea is viable or not.

The project focus on the transferability of knowledge into real-world application is expected to increase students' persistence in engineering majors. Howard University and New Mexico State University will each implement a one week immersive experience for 40 incoming transfer students using Lean LaunchPad as the format. The transfer students will work in teams to explore the business model canvas, immersing themselves in core portions of the scientific method in an experiential, inquiry based, learner centered environment. In addition, Howard University will adopt and adapt the proven successful NMSU transfer student recruitment methods.

The broader significance and importance of this project is in the innovative use of Lean LaunchPad to ease the transition for incoming transfer students. Community colleges enroll over half of all Hispanic students and 41% of all African American students. This target population has enormous potential for broadening participation in the engineering workforce. Of equal importance is the fact that this research project will address the lack of evidenced based interventions that support the success of transfer students. The success of this project as evidenced by improved retention and graduation numbers can be replicated across varying institutional types.

This project overlaps with NSF's strategic goals of broadening participation in the engineering workforce. The transfer student population is extremely diverse in multiple ways; gender, race, age being the most obvious. The population is growing and increasingly includes veterans returning from active duty. By targeting transfer students, introducing them to entrepreneurship from an engineering perspective and supporting their transition to a four year institution, this project will evaluate the impact of a Lean LaunchPad based immersive experience on their success in earning undergraduate engineering degrees.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2015, Howard University and New Mexico State University (a Hispanic-serving institution) began piloting the Lean Launchpad methodology as a mechanism for engaging new transfer students. The project, funded by a Broadening Participation in Engineering (BPE) grant from the National Science Foundation, engages new transfer students from engineering and computer science departments in a weeklong summer program designed to promote retention through early development of relationships with engineering faculty and students and early experiences that enhance skills needed for success as engineers and computer scientists in the innovative workplace of the 21st century.

The program curriculum is a five-day adaptation of the Lean Launchpad course curriculum. Participants are presented with a design challenge that requires them to meet and interact with students on campus and in the surrounding community in order to develop a viable solution to a real-world campus need. Example projects include innovations in bicycle storage, campus security, and campus-related smart phone applications. Completing the project requires participants to utilize the Lean LaunchPad methodology and explore product market fit.  Students engage in customer discovery and agile development to rapidly test and iterate product designs. Each morning, students participate in interactive classroom lessons that focus on Lean Launchpad principles. In the afternoons, they apply the principles in real-time by interviewing potential consumers about the product or service they are designing and compiling interview data into recommendations for revision to their product design. This process also enhances valuable communication skills, as participants present their findings and resulting changes daily. The experience is guided by faculty members and continuing students, on each campus. Students serve as peer mentors and help introduce the new transfer students to the campus.

 

Evaluations suggest that the program is effectively engaging new transfer students and promoting their confidence to pursue engineering studies. Twenty-two students have completed the program at Howard in three summer offerings to date (2015, 2016, 2017, and 2018). The sample size is lower than initially expected and has led to a need for adjustments in the evaluation plan. Still, important findings that are informing future program plans have emerged. For example, many eligible students were unable to participate in the program due to internship and work obligations. As the team considers options for institutionalizing the program, shifts in the program schedule will be necessary to expand participation. Many new transfer students cannot commit to programming that requires eight hours a day for five weekdays prior to the start of classes. Condensing the schedule to integrate the program into new student orientation activities or introductory coursework for transfer students is expected to increase the number of students who are able to benefit from participation.

Another essential finding has been to focus less on having students master entrepreneurial concepts in theory and focus more on their experience and the benefits they can derive from the experiential learning process.  In the inaugural offering (summer 2015), participants were guided through the majority of the business model canvas, which forms the basis for the Lean Launchpad approach, in the five-day program. Evaluation results showed that about 80% of students felt overwhelmed with the quantity of concepts that were introduced in such a short time. These results informed a change for the second summer offering to focus only on two key aspects of the business model canvas (customer discovery and value proposition) that would maximize participants’ interaction with the campus community and engineering design process. Summer 2016 evaluations revealed more positive reactions to the Lean Launchpad experience. In addition, the Howard participants, especially, indicated an ability to bond with other students that was statistically significantly stronger [t (14) = 2.20, p <.05] than the response in the previous year (mean of 3.50 in Summer 2015 versus a mean of 4.00 in Summer of 2016).

One encouraging finding is the program’s ability to sustain students’ strong interest and motivation to pursue engineering over the course of the five-week program.  Specifically, when asked to rate their level of agreement with three items measuring their commitment to pursuing engineering, students responded with a score of 3.84 on average before receiving the program and responded with a 4.02 after receiving the program.  There were statistically significant positive shifts in students acquiring a stronger engineering identity [t (12) =-2.31, p < .05], and perceiving strong value in majoring in engineering [t (12) =-2.91, p < .01]  after receiving the 5-week program.  One benefit to offering the program prior to the start of orientation activities and classes is the ability to better isolate the effects of the program in evaluation.
